pros: The company culture is impressive, and filled with helpful, highly competent professionals. I work in the CPC department (communications, policy and campaigns) and I can say that my colleagues are always ready to help out when there is a query. We have flexible work hours that start between 8 am-10am, and management understands personal needs too.
cons: Salary is low but what can you expect in the charity sector?

cons: Low salaries and frustrations at lack of resources.

review_title: A lovely organisation to work with where you make a huge difference to others lives

Benefits and flexibility. Opportunities for ongoing personal development Living by your values I get to choose how much I would like to work from home or the office.
cons: Not earning the same as non-charity companies

pros: Great team to work with

pros: Friendly staff and a good cause

job_title: Resettlement Officer in Preston, North West England, England
pros: Keeps you busy, decent management and knowledge based support structure.
cons: Paper trail madness, expect alot for a little, theres no way you cant be overloaded with work and not stressed, or run ragged. I.e 2 laptops hundreds off passwords, and no provision in place for resttling housing, ownerous is on you. Caseload can reach over 100 clients

review_title: Talented and hard-working people, but management issues
pros:
Brilliant campaign teams working collaboratively on projects. 
Talented and knowledgeable staff across policy, research, campaigns, public affairs, legal and press.
cons:
My cons are specific to the team I worked on: bullying and controlling manager, who belittled staff on our team, and also on others. They rewrote all our work during every sign-off, which is a waste of everyone's time. 
Mock "consultation" was carried out when a campaign was axed - and we found out it was bogus, as the decision had already been made.
Some senior management were ineffective.

pros: Good fun work with good camaraderie
cons: Management were not competent and take advantage of employees. You're expected to work outside of London and are not paid for the hours it takes to travel there, which can be as much as three hours of unpaid travel for a six hour shift.

review_title: Good pay, good environment, not stable at all
job_title: Charity Fundraiser in Manchester City Centre, England
pros: The environment and people were very good.
cons: However, very target based, not many second chances and therefore not stable

pros: You will work alongside some amazing people, really driven by making a difference.
cons:
Toxic culture - people too scared to speak up. 

Patronising leadership & a brainwashing operation - do not work here unless you love the Communist Manifesto & sing Red Flag every morning. 

A lot of focus on diversity and inclusion but only want the inclusion of those who don’t ask questions, with the ‘right’ (far-left) opinions. 

Talk the talk on mental health & wellbeing but don’t actually do a great deal practically - expected to take endless abuse (including death threats) off your clients because they’re more important than you as an employee. 

Nothing really done to support people returning to work following sickness. 

Clueless management - don’t identify bullying & other issues, when highlighted it is not addressed.

Poor provision for employees with disabilities - took 4 months to get appropriate equipment. 

Sucks up all funding, subcontracts work to smaller charities (for a pittance) & takes a slice of the funding - presumably to pay their overpaid CEO and leadership team.

review_title: Team are lovely, management shockingly abusive
pros: The people you work on the team with is extremely lovely, such a wonderful bunch of characters and you’re working for such a great cause
cons: The manager of the streets team has absolutely no idea what motivation is, he guilt trips, stresses and makes you feel horrible if you have any mental health issues, he has absolutely no idea what acting professional is at all

pros: Working towards the aim of improving housing in the UK is a great personal passion, Shelter allows me to put the passion into action and get people the help they need!
cons:
Pay!
Lack of community culture internally,
Poor management structure.

review_title: Great ethos. Strong union. Great colleagues.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Old Street, England
pros:
- Great cause and motivating to be part of it. 
- Many motivated and skilled people who are working to improve the lives of homeless people and those facing poor housing conditions.
- Staff are dedicated and very respectful of each other.
- Very good annual leave and maternity leave. 
- Very active and supportive Union. 
- Healthy reserves. 
- Good flexible working and work life balance (can't physically be in the office past 7pm!)
cons:
- A lot of middle managers. 
- The senior leadership team keep trying year on year to reduce pensions and offer tiny pay rises that are not in line with inflation. They tried to do this or something similar every year, and if it weren't for the Union pushing back staff would have got a bad deal. 
- Disconnect between head office and services. 
- Silos between teams often causes inefficiency, but this is common across the 3rd sector and it's always being addressed. 
- Top down hierarchical structure frustrating and some in the senior leadership team don't seem to understand the jobs of the teams they manage and cause sign off problems on projects.

pros: Nice company, friendly team to be apart of
cons: Weren't always a lot of staff to assistant when needed

pros: Forward thinking and very friendly
cons: None I can think of

review_title: Get overworked and underpaid at the homelessness industry's leading brand
pros: The company paid on time.
cons:
- A tendency among senior management staff to promote and favour staff who are inadequate at their jobs in spite of complaints against them
- Waited until the eleventh hour before the start of a strike to give desperately underpaid frontline staff an absolutely minimal pay rise, all the while paying back office 'campaign' and 'donor' staff at least 10% more than frontline staff across the board
- Management would rather report overworked staff to line managers instead of offering support when they are clearly struggling
- Slavish devotion to stats resulting in a lack of person-centred support for front-line staff who frequently take sick leave for mental health reasons 
- Mentions of bullying and inappropriate behaviour of line managers in exit form go totally unacknowledged

job_title: Campaign Manager in City of London, England
pros: The salary is good and location is excellent.
cons: I was targeted by a less experienced member of staff, who was extremely abusive. He threw furniture at me while swearing, threatened me and made me afraid to come into work. When I raised this with management they refused to let me take the matter to HR. I felt afraid to come into work, yet their solution was to sit me next to him, so that we ‘could resolve our differences and work together’. Not only was he in an entirely different department, but working together wasn’t relevant to my role. It was almost as if they were enjoying the drama and the fear this man (who they also admitted to me was experiencing mental health issues) was instilling in me. When I asked what measures were to be put in place for my own safety at work, they replied “none”. I resigned the same day for my own safety and have been left with a terrible opinion of this charity.

review_title: I worked as a street fundraiser for just over a year and I wouldn't take it back for the world!
pros: The team ethic is amazing. Everyone supports each other, looks out for each other and really works as a group. There's very little hierarchy and a lot of empathy and compassion.
cons: Any street fundraising job is hard. It is mentally straining, everyone is a little bit crazy, and the public aren't the nicest. However, it takes a certain person to be a successful fundraiser so don't go for it unless you have thick skin and confidence in your cause, because once you're in you'll never want to leave!

pros: Shelter attracts some of the loveliest people to volunteer for them in their shops, they are a pleasure to work with.
cons: The company is disorganised and doesn't manage their paid shop staff properly at all. There are numerous staffing problems that are mismanaged, when they take a liking to particular members of staff they become blinkered to their behaviour causing many many issues and disharmony in the work place. I have never worked within a company that has so much drama on a daily basis and I have witnessed this in more than one of their shops, it's truly disgraceful.

pros: I’m glad I did it so that when I’m somewhere else I can appreciate it for how good it is compared to that awful job. It’s been humbling.
cons: Isn’t it against the law to fire someone with no warning like that? I managed a few sign ups but it wasn’t enough.  I got fired after 2 weeks. I was desperate for a job at the time and wish I never wasted my time and energy. Also very exhausting, I got told I had to walk faster in sweltering heat each day, when I already walk fast. I was with all men and I’m a shorter girl, so that wasn’t taken into account. The whole thing is quite culty and patronising.

pros:
Excellent training and support offered. 
Friendly and helpful staff with amazing team ethic.
cons:
Really tight with sign-ups. I was fired mid-week by the deputy manager whilst the manager was away because it looked like I wasn't going to meet the number of sign-ups. Wasn't even given the chance to prove I could do it. 
Fundraising is a really difficult job in general, but it is so rewarding.

review_title: Good volunteering experience with a great, helpful team
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
- Flexible and more than willing to adjust the role according to the volunteer's strengths/interests.
- Everyone on the team is friendly and happy to help if you have any issues.
cons: Whether or not this is a con depends on the volunteer, but I found the workplace to be a little too relaxed, with my role not having any deadlines or very challenging tasks. This left me feeling like somewhat of a burden, as I would often approach other members of staff asking for things that I could be doing.

review_title: Could make you homeless by offering you a job
pros: Okay hourly rate and weekly pay.
cons:
- working in the freezing cold and rain 
-unrealistic targets 
-only ONE days training.. 
-will probably fire you on your 2nd or 3rd day if you can’t meet said unrealistic targets 
-therefore, be out of work, with no actual warning, 2-3 days in. Definitely don’t leave employment to work here. If you’re volunteering or need work experience then this is probably okay for that.

pros:
Being surrounded by super intelligent people is great, it pushes you to learn and improve.
Everyone is quite passionate about the cause.
Freedom to work from home or wherever.
Honestly feel like you're making a difference to the housing crisis
cons:
Hierarchical structure is horrible - with increasingly confusing levels of sign off for projects.
Lack of opportunities for staff to progress through organisation.

review_title: Amazing staff to work with, unorganised management however
pros: Helping out an amazing charity which does a lot of work to battle the fight against homelessness. Friendly work environment and the staff are lovely. Opportunities to progress to a certain degree
cons: Management are unorganised and can be rude, very target based, a lot of pressure to deal with. Very high staff turn over.

pros: Shelter was a great place to work with incredibly talented and passionate staff. The organisation does an amazing job helping homeless and vulnerable people with housing issues.
cons: Due to the organisation having a large number of different activities there is not always a good understanding between different teams & divisions. Occasional industrial actions and redundancy.

pros: Shelter is generally a great place to work. colleagues are friendly and supportive and the expertise across the whole organisation is incredible.
cons: saying that, we have gone through a lot of change over the last couple of years which has caused a lot of uncertainty. hopefully this will calm down now we have a full senior leadership team in place and are developing a new strategy.

review_title: Great colleagues but unhappy, disenchanted and demotivated workforce
pros: On the whole, lovely people to work with and varied caseload.
cons: Level of work is unmanageable, and people often have to work outside normal working hours to stay a float but falling behind is inevitable. Pressure of meeting targets and dealing with demanding clients is so high that the organisation has a high turnover of staff and sickness due to work related stress.

pros: Friendly people. Nice animals. God work. Good pay. Very clean and safe environment for all people and animals great job overall
cons: I’m my experience there wasn’t any cons with the ACTYALLY job more the pay I found minimum wage wasn’t allot for all the hard work we have had to do

review_title: Intense, bit mad and lots of fun
pros:
Really great people 
Great opportunities there for the taking 
Amazing cause
You can make things happen as nothing is set in stone
Supportive and welcoming
Diverse teams
cons:
A little all over the place 
Lots and lots of meetings 
Staff turnover 
Change in CEO and top management means a lot of staff insecurity and instability recently. I'm sure it will settle though

job_title: Community Shop Manager in London, England
pros: Working with Volunteers and being there at the birth of a worthwhile initiative.
cons:
The new Boutiques have all the look of smart retail units. Good step away from all the bad connotations of charity shops full of tat. Only if the mentality of the key players running Shelter also took a step forward. 

You might not be getting the necessary support but you will still be held responsible for meeting the targets.

 My contract was written for 35hrs. I worked 45 plus. HR response will tell you I chose to work those hours. Not true, and they know it. The other Boutique managers, too, work even longer hours and go without days off at times for a week. I refused to work seven days in a go. If you like this job be prepared to do the extra extra hours , you will be "in". 

After hours merchandising was not a free choice, I was needed on the shop floor during opening hours. The business was just building up so training volunteers was a fundamental part of my day.  Yet I was told to stop working  the extra hours. With hindsight this was to ascertain they had proof they did not break my Contract by getting me work more hours than  contracted. If you are under probation you can still claim for unfair dismissal if your employer breaks  any of the points in your Contract.  

 I am about hard work, but also against exploitation in the workplace so I asked for help from my line manager. She,  instead giving support I had been promised, not written in Contract, but in my interview,  I was told I failed to live up to the terms of my Contract and was therefore terminated there and then. Although the Contract did never stipulate the sum of the weekly target my Appeal was turned down. To say I feel robbed, of my efforts, my rights for fairness, and my professional standing is no exaggeration.

I was not given fair treatment during my entire work with Shelter. Another person left a feedback about that on 10th July, she is spot on. If you have professional standards this organisation is not for you. 

So be aware that the Contract you sign is not full set of documentation that will tie you to your post. Your choice, my story is a one off as I was openly discussing shortcomings.

pros:
Incredible diversity in the workforce and really friendly atmosphere (Kind of a required personality type for the job). 
Great experience to enhance communication skills.
Good pay and incentive-based rewards system
cons: Difficult job: you are required to make 3 sign ups a day in direct debit though the managing staff are understanding of "bad weeks".

cons: You have to work through very poor conditons. Even when it is pooring down with rain you. Some members of the public can be very rude , but the amazing team you have support you.

cons: No cons to report at Shelter!
